name: q19_8
probTex: Prove that the Dolbeault cohomology group $H_X^{\;1,1}$ is isomorphic to $\mathbb{C}$, where $X$ is a compact Riemann surface.
solnTex:
First consider the evaluation map $ev:H_X^{\;1,1}	o\mathbb{C}$ given by $ev(ho) = \int_X ho$. We claim that this gives an isomorphism of vector spaces between $H_X^{\;1,1}$ and $\mathbb{C}$. To show $ev$ is well defined, suppose $[ho] = [	au]$. Then $ho-	au\in im\left(\overline{\partial}ight)$ by the way $H_X^{\;1,1}$ is defined. Let $ho - 	au = \overline{\partial}f(z)dz$, this is possible because $ho-	au\in im\left(\overline{\partial}ight)$. By using Stokes theorem along with the fact $\partial f(z)dz =  rac{\partial f}{\partial z}dz\wedge dz=0$, we have
\[ev(ho-	au)=\int_X\overline{\partial}f(z)dz=\int_X dfdz=\int_{\partial X}f(z)dz=\int_{\emptyset}f(z)dz=0.\]
Hence the evaluation map is well defined. Also $ev$ is a linear map since integration is linear.
To show that $ev$ is surjective, recall (if you happen to have seen it before) that any orientable manifold admits a nowhere-vanishing volume form. Since $X$ is orientable, and volume forms for Riemann surfaces are $(1,1)$ forms (think $dz\wedge d\overline z$), let $ho$ be a nowhere-vanishing volume form. Then $ev(ho)
eq0$. We can rescale the integral by considering $aho$ for $a\in\mathbb{C}$ if need be to get any $c\in\mathbb{C}$, so $ev$ is surjective.
Now assume $ev(ho) = 0$. We want to show $ho \in im(\overline{\partial})$ so that $ho = [0]$ in the cohomology class. Consider the equation given by $\overline{\partial}\partial f = ho$. A fundamental PDE result says the existence of a solution to this equation happens iff $ev(ho) = 0$. By assumption, we can find $\alpha = \partial f$ such that $\overline{\partial}\alpha = ho$. Thus $ho \in im(\overline{\partial})$, hence $ho = [0]$. Thus the map is injective. Thus the spaces are isomorphic.
